citations.narrative:
Two approximate 8 week old domestic kittens did not have official identification on them at the time of inspection. Official
identification is required for APHIS officials to properly identify animals at the facility and trace their movements. Live
kittens, less than 16 weeks of age, shall be identified by an official tag as described in § 2.51, a distinctive and legible
tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or a plastic-type collar acceptable to the Administrator which has legibly
placed thereon the information required for an official tag pursuant to Sec. 2.51.
To be corrected by 10-June-2024.

The facility is missing the full address of the individual two calves were obtained from and the name and full addresses of
the individuals three domestic kittens, 4 peafowl, 38 domestic chickens and 9 domestic ducks were obtained from.
Acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals during inspection and to
properly trace their movements.
Each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. These
records shall include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired from, the USDA license
or registration number of the person if they are licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and state and the
driver's license number and state of the person if they are not licensed under the Act, the name and address of the person
to whom an animal was sold or given to, the date of the purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of the animal, the species
of the animal, and the number of animals in the shipment.
The facility must create and maintain a record of acquisition information for the animals. The facility must ensure all
required information is properly and accurately documented at all times.
To be corrected by: 10-June-2024

A large bag of cat kibble was opened and set on the floor of the food storage barn. The cat food was placed in a covered
trash can at the time of inspection. Uncovered supplies of food may allow the for possible contamination from mammalian
or insect pests and spoilage of the food. All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with
tightly fitting lids to prevent contamination and spoilage.
To be corrected by: 6-June-2024

During the inspection, one approximate 8 week old domestic kitten was found right outside of its primary enclosure and
the door of the enclosure was still closed. The kitten was returned to its primary enclosure immediately. Primary
enclosures that do not contain animal securely may result in animal escape and/or injury. Primary enclosures must be
constructed and maintained so that they contain the cats securely.
To be corrected: 6-June-2024

A section of green, uncoated chicken wire with several sharp points is attached to the inside of the chicken and duck
primary enclosure fence at the height of the adult birds. Sharp points may cause injury to the birds housed within. Primary
enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds.
To be corrected by: 6-June-2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Two approximate 8 week old domestic kittens did not have official identification on them at the time of inspection. Official 
identification is required for APHIS officials to properly identify animals at the facility and trace their movements. Live 
kittens, less than 16 weeks of age, shall be identified by an official tag as described in § 2.51, a distinctive and legible 
tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or a plastic-type collar acceptable to the Administrator which has legibly 
placed thereon the information required for an official tag pursuant to Sec. 2.51. 
To be corrected by 10-June-2024. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is missing the full address of the individual two calves were obtained from and the name and full addresses of 
the individuals three domestic kittens, 4 peafowl, 38 domestic chickens and 9 domestic ducks were obtained from. 
Acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals during inspection and to 
properly trace their movements. 
Each exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control. These 
records shall include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired from, the USDA license 
or registration number of the person if they are licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and state and the 
driver's license number and state of the person if they are not licensed under the Act, the name and address of the person 
to whom an animal was sold or given to, the date of the purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of the animal, the species 
of the animal, and the number of animals in the shipment. 
The facility must create and maintain a record of acquisition information for the animals. The facility must ensure all 
required information is properly and accurately documented at all times. 
To be corrected by: 10-June-2024 
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

A large bag of cat kibble was opened and set on the floor of the food storage barn. The cat food was placed in a covered 
trash can at the time of inspection. Uncovered supplies of food may allow the for possible contamination from mammalian 
or insect pests and spoilage of the food. All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with 
tightly fitting lids to prevent contamination and spoilage.  
To be corrected by: 6-June-2024 
3.6(a)(2)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
During the inspection, one approximate 8 week old domestic kitten was found right outside of its primary enclosure and 
the door of the enclosure was still closed. The kitten was returned to its primary enclosure immediately. Primary 
enclosures that do not contain animal securely may result in animal escape and/or injury. Primary enclosures must be 
constructed and maintained so that they contain the cats securely. 
To be corrected: 6-June-2024 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A section of green, uncoated chicken wire with several sharp points is attached to the inside of the chicken and duck 
primary enclosure fence at the height of the adult birds. Sharp points may cause injury to the birds housed within. Primary 
enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. 
To be corrected by: 6-June-2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
